I wholeheartedly agree with your comments, and I think you expressed them in a compassionate way. Yes, we need to take care of ourselves after we experience the painful loss of those who mean so much to us. Is there a more balanced way to cope with loss than the author described in this piece? Hard to tell. She is surely fortunate that she could affort the medical and especially the psychiatric care that she received. The average person in American often has to wait months for such care, and most people receive antidepressants, tranquilizers, etc. from the primary care doctors, not specialists.

Don't get me wrong - I believe grief support is important, and should be accessible to all. Normal grief, however, is NOT a psychiatric condition. This woman would probably have benefitted more from support from friends and family, as well as others who have lost their parents. She is lucky she was able to access and to pay to have psychiatrists provide this service.

The important thing to recognize is that the psychological/psychiatric "care" she received was more harmful then beneficial. She was finally able to start healing after she put clinical psychology's pathologizing thoughts and behaviors behind her.

Lori, I think you are mistaken in your assessment of kri's remarks. Some of us had parents who basically told us that "life is hard and then you die - so you'd better buck up, and enjoy what you can while you can".  We DO tend to look at people who don't, can't, or won't react in such a pragmatic manner as "soft" - but underneath it all we sometimes wish that we could have believed (once) in a safer world. I learned decades ago that there is one safe place and time - and that's when you're safely 6 feet under.

Does anyone think her father was using his small daughter as his own emotional crutch?  My mother died when I was a teenager and I still survived as I was not allowed to fester her loss.  Mourn, yes.  But, then I had to keep house for my Dad, and myself, go to school, get a part-time job, wprepare for college, etc.  It was hard to see my father weep, but everything is a learning experience.  I learned how to handle grief and loss with dignity, not loss of control.  Death is a normal part of life.  The hardest types of death with which to deal, I feel, are those of a parent for a child, either through disease or accident (or bombing, either in our country or another).  The death of a parent is in the normal course of life's progression.  To make it a specialized tragedy, depending on cause, is maybe a bit presumptuous.  Until we conquer illness, we better learn how to deal.  It has been going on for a long, long, time.  Better to pass on strength of character to our children than emotional collapse.  Sorry if I seem callous, but just speaking from experience, as have others in this comment section.

I saw no police in the background next to the buildings on the sidewalk. I saw the overhead photographs of the streets. As a society, a premium is placed on achievement and individual accomplishment. In moments crisis, individual achievements blur. Lines of achievement blur. Power, position and status blur. Individuals blur. It is the collective spirit that needs to be in the forefront. There have been many marathons in the past. But in this marathon, many innocent lives have been lost to the insanity of the ruthless act of someone.  The unrealized dreams and potentials and livelihood have been dissipated in the blood-spilled afternoon massacre. How can these innocent lives ever cross the lines that they set out to march towards?

My heart goes out to the victims and those who love them--
and to all the runners who trained so hard,
only to have their efforts put to naught by this awful attack.

I had the same reaction as you did to many comments.

Although the NYT comments are much better than those found elsewhere, the tone of comments here depends on the nature of the article -- election coverage, philosophical topics, the death of a celebrity all elicit typical patterns. Stories about tragedies such as this, as well as the Newtown murders, bring out a predictable range of comments. These are not just condolences and expressions of grief but also appreciations of those who helped. Speculations (occasionally wild and irresponsible but at times well-informed), criticism of news coverage, and unanswered questions are often presented. Political remarks are not out of place -- the argument that "now is not the time to discuss policies" can stifle conversation when it is needed -- but the politics should be focused on the issue at hand. Sometimes posters of comments bring the discussion around to their favorite bete noir (germane to the issue or not), criticism of a particular politician or agency, animus against an ethnic group, or personal religious beliefs or unbeliefs.

It is clear that many of the readers who sent in comments are on edge, affected by Monday's terrible events and the material in this article. Perhaps this accentuates short tempers, not always well-considered words, and impoliteness in a few comments. By publishing so many comments, including intemperate ones, the NYT may not be enlightening the public but does provide a vehicle for mourning.

I am saddened by the callousness of many of these comments as well as the cheerleaders.
Perhaps mourning is something so frightening for these people that they must confuse themselves with platitudes or forced matter-of-factness.
Either way I think it's disrespectful to those affected.

As someone who for over half a century has usually struggled most days with one or more symptoms of mental illness, I sympathise with your indignation. Nonetheless, the picture is rather more complex than the one you paint. Most of us will experience periods of mental illness at one or more times between the cradle and the grave, just as most of us will experience physical illness at least once during this time.

Some folks will never experience mental illness, just as others will never have a day of physical illness in their lives. But both groups make up a small minority. At the other end of the spectrum, some folks contend with extreme mental and physical illness from the moment they are born until their last breath. Mental illness and physical illness are normal for most humans. Hence, in my view, the distinction you draw between those who are mentally or physically ill and those you label as 'normies' is invalid.

Illness is a slippery slope. It's frightening how quickly things can unravel when one can't function properly mentally or physically. Incapacity soon leads to unemployment. Unemployment all too readily leads to homelessness, which in turn leads to near complete social isolation. In the USA, it's sink or swim. Those of us who survive in more civilized, humane and caring societies have everything for which to be grateful.

However, that does not mean my obese friends and relatives who have had to use psychotropics should "just get over it, eat better, and exercise." My heart breaks for them and the horrible challenge they feel from their very own brains, their own bodies.
I am grateful for this study and the measured, hopeful progress the subjects were able to make. I am hopeful that more will be learned and more will become possible for those who must fight this battle.
Walk a mile in their shoes seems a decent guideline. I do not believe my loved ones are lazier or stupider or less moral than I am. It is obviously a heartbreaking situation. I hope for general progress in this area. Soon.

We still don't know the full affect of psychiatric medication. Eleven years ago I gained thirty pounds in month from rispedal at age 14. Rispedal caused me to get PCOS a hormonal imbalance caused mainly by an insulin Resistance. Before I was diagnosed with pcos i was working out 5 days a week and watching what I ate did not lose a pound. I even completed a 28 day backpacking trip in the wilderness. There was a time where it felt out of control, know one knew why my weight was the way it it was.

The difficult thing is knowing that I probably would not have as many issues with my weight if it has not been for the medication I am grateful that the medication allows me to lead a normal life- but frustrated and the medical community's. Reluctance to admit some of the medications side affects. I am happy to read that they are trying too tackle the issue of weight gain and mental illness though community programs but hope they learn more about medications long term effects on people.

All of this information is available with a quick Google search. If you want to build a bomb or kill people, you can find that information in plenty of forums outside of the New York Times. For most of us, however, it provides useful information about what to be aware of in our surroundings and how it could have happened.

This horrible, tragic event is terrible enough. But to provide so much information about the bombs, how they were made, and where to find directions to make them online—now what if other crazy terrorists and mentally ill people create more havoc. I believe in transparency, however, there are some things that should be kept confidential. These reporters need to use some common sense and so do their editors.

This hideous attack reminded me almost immediately of the Centennial Olympic Park Bombing during the summer 1996 Olympics.

Both bombings happened in sporting venues in which people would likely be off their guard and attending to ongoing, exciting and absorbing events.

However, the 1996 attack - which is carefully documented on Wikipedia - occurred before we as a nation became fully aware of a need for comprehensive surveillance measures in public places in an new age of domestic and foreign terrorism.

Solving that crime therefore required long, careful investigative work - with a famous false start that almost wrecked the life of a man who had been identified as a hero.

But this one likely won't be difficult to solve, because there were plenty of security measures in place - and dozens, if not hundreds of digital-age still and video cameras recording from many angles the areas of the bombings.

Those facts would make the Marathon a poor choice for a foreign terrorist organization which would not want to risk an embarrassing failure at the start.

Also, there is the apparently primitive build of the explosive devices, which, it seems, did not use high explosives that could be easily manufactured by a sophisticated terrorist outfit.

So I think that even though this crime was a conspiracy, it likely was brought off by a domestic U.S. group which is a haven for people who harbor political grudges against our government or possibly against the Boston Marathon.

The problem with the "see something say something" way of thinking is that it turns everyone into suspicous informants who rat out neighbors who maybe aren't doing anything wrong.  It calls for completely rational thought and good intentions but, well, Lord of the Flies comes to mind.  I appreciate the police but I am not rushing to give them any more power than they already have.  And where is the line drawn?  You want to know what is in my bag?  Then what, my house? Uh, my mind?  Sorry, but it's important not to give away freedoms.  I appreciate your intentions but I am uncomfortable with some of the suggestions.

this is a no brainer. colour coding. there are millions of colors. even my computer can generate them. everyone should be assigned a colour (we should use both RGB or CMYK) and if you put down or leave your package, it will be returned to you automatically. this would work especially well for those who actually lose something. can you even imagine someone unwilling to participate in this scheme? if they did, it would say a lot, and the police might even want to know who they are.

the only problem i can see is what if two people want the same color? it could be based on a 'first come, first serve' basis.

This might not have been the easiest thing to do in the chaos of the event, but although people are talking about this way and that way to prevent this sort of thing from happening again, I feel like the "If you see something, say something" campaign is the best way I can think of to catch those terrorists that slip past the other safeguards. I can sit on the couch and think of all kinds of ways to obtain all the items needed for these devices without rousing suspicion and setting off the "tripwire." But I should be worried about having my plot foiled by someone seeing me going around and dropping off random black bags. Granted, in the confusion of a large crowd, I can see how one could pull it off without being obvious, such as by acting casual, dressing to blend-in, and  making it appear that the bag belongs to a member of the crowd. Perhaps we, as a society, should find some way to make it very clear what bag belongs to whom (even in a large crowd), so we don't risk making assumptions that a bag belongs to somebody when it actually belongs to no one present? Such as by somehow creating or modifying a social norm?  Does that make any sense? And if so... any ideas on how to do this?

David, I appreciate your points. However, I thought that, in a sense, that is what war is for: if one side is not experiencing war and killing on the ground, but from a remote and safe place, I don't see the moral equivalency there. And in that case, what is the barrier to war? People protest when they do not want to go to war, or send their sons and daughters off, because they worry for their safety. If there are no safety concerns for "our side," what is to prevent us -- or any user of drones -- from endlessly picking off the ones we don't like? How do we differentiate between that and, for example, Pinochet's minions, who at least got their hands dirty as they murdered and could not pretend to themselves that they hadn't.

We should avoid the drain on our souls by staying out of wars to the best --truly the best -- of our ability. If there are no consequences to war, no worries about draining our souls, then it's all too easy to do.
